main_text:
Objections || The Indeterminacy Objection
6.2 The Indeterminacy Objection

Critics have argued that public reason liberals embrace excessively
indeterminate conceptions of justice. The ideal of public
justification cannot make determinate recommendations. Gaus (2011)
presses this objection against Rawlsian conceptions of public
justification, resolving indeterminacy by appealing to actual
evolutionary mechanisms (see 2.7.4). This “normalization”
objection rejects attempts to avoid indeterminacy by adopting
homogenizing assumptions. (D’Agostino 2003)
